body: Thanks @jhamrick ! Technically, this looks fine, we'll just have to work out if it's what we want to do?

I believe locked would also mean not editable in user minds (and would set CodeMirror to nocursor). So I would be carefull with naming. 

Note that no cursor might not be good as you cannot copy text.

Envoyé de mon iPhone

> Le 17 sept. 2014 à 19:40, Thomas Kluyver notifications@github.com a écrit :
> 
> Thanks @jhamrick ! Technically, this looks fine, we'll just have to work out if it's what we want to do?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

And this example might be overkill with this PR:

https://github.com/ipython/ipython/blob/master/IPython/html/static/notebook/js/celltoolbarpresets/example.js

Envoyé de mon iPhone

> Le 17 sept. 2014 à 19:40, Thomas Kluyver notifications@github.com a écrit :
> 
> Thanks @jhamrick ! Technically, this looks fine, we'll just have to work out if it's what we want to do?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

Yeah, I definitely don't want "locked" to mean "uneditable" -- so maybe that calls for a different name, or something. I tried to get that example to work but it seemed to throw an error when I tried to load it; I'll try playing around with it more later (and file another PR if it is actually broken ;))
Maybe 'pinned'?
I think "pinned" would also imply "unmoveable". In the dev meeting just now we talked about calling it "deleteable", which I like.
Though that does raise a question of spelling. I would have thought 'deletable' ;-)
Yeah. Google seems to agree that 'deletable' is the correct spelling, so let's go with that.

Ok, updated the name. I still think there should be some visual indicator of whether a cell is deletable or not -- I will try to come up with something over the weekend (probably don't have time today).
If you're feeling keen, it would be good to have a test for this.
Would it be useful to have both `deletable` and `editable` options, and visual representations for both?

@takluyver augh, thanks for catching those mistakes. I didn't get enough sleep last night; I think I'll work on this more later (tomorrow) when I'm thinking more clearly. 

And yeah, it would definitely be good to have a test... do you know where the best place to put it would be? I didn't see a natural place from looking (quickly) at the existing tests -- it doesn't seem like `delete_cell` itself is being tested at all?

It doesn't look like there's an existing file, but it should go in `IPython/html/tests/notebook`. There are already tests for inserting and moving cells, so I guess adding a new file for deleting makes sense. Don't call it `dualmode_foo`, though; that makes Min sad.

What is your policy regarding this kind of features? Is it a one-off decision for each case, or do you want to specify (as part of the ipynb format) a general framework for things like, locked cells, cells skipped in a run-all, cell-level breakpoints etc (or any of the things that got implemented and hacked as extensions?) 
A lot of those are very natural usecases.

Broadly we want those things to be done as extensions. Some of us think this one warrants an exception, because if you want to prevent a class of students from accidentally deleting a cell in a homework notebook, you can't expect them all to install an extension for that. Others think it should be in an extension anyway, at least for now.
And that reminds me, where did cell tagging get to?

Just a thought: I was not getting the point of preventing cell deletion but not edition, at least until you mention that this is "to prevent a class of students from accidentally deleting a cell in a homework notebook".
Then I think it would be better to mark the cell as deletable:false in metadata, but instead of a visual indicator on the cell, it would be preferable to raise a warning popup when somebody try to delete it. The popup would say that this cell is protected from deletion  (with eventually an additional information on how to remove this "lock" or a pointer where to find this information). To me, any permanent visual information that the cell is not deletable would be noise...

> And that reminds me, where did cell tagging get to?

Pierre closed his PR, and will reopen simpler one when less PhD on his plate.

- We decided that we are +1 on this
- Need to document all official metadata that we support (@minrk will add this to the nbformat 4 PR #6045 )
Need a few more changes of logic.

For the record: I agree that we should document what we use, but I don't think optional metadata that we use in the notebook UI or in nbconvert is part of the notebook format (in terms of schema, versioning, etc.)

I didn't add validation of the metadata to the PR, it's just that PR is the only place that there is documentation of what's stored in a notebook, so I added the metadata table to that doc. Plus, nbformat 4 moves a few cell attributes (collapsed, language) to metadata.

Ok, I've made the necessary changes and added a whole bunch of tests. I added a dialog warning the user (thanks for those examples @Carreau !):

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/83444/4397169/d2ebede6-443d-11e4-8b4d-0174491bc0fe.png)

I also added a test utility function to handle waiting for a dialog to open, doing something, then waiting for it to close, then doing something else. I based this code off of what was in the `dualmode.js` tests, and then edited `dualmode.js` to use the utility function instead of what it had before.

Finally, I realized that if we're preventing the deletion of cells, that should probably also imply:
- Un-deletable cells should not be able to be merged with other cells
- Un-deletable cells should not be able to be split into two cells
- Copying and pasting an un-deletable cell should probably not result in another un-deletable cell

The last two commits implement these additional changes. If people don't like them I can revert those commits, but I think it makes sense to have that behavior because merging is a form of deletion, and then if we allow splitting it's kind of weird, because then you can split an undeletable cell but not merge it back together.

It is also currently problematic that the metadata is lost (and thus the cell becomes deletable) if the cell type is changed, which is a common thing to do accidentally. This will be fixed by #6472 though.
Hmmm, apparently the changes I made are causing the `dualmode.js` tests to fail. They pass fine on my computer, so I'm not sure what the issue is, but I'll try to figure it out...
Ok, javascript tests are passing now! The tests that are failing aren't javascript -- my code shouldn't have affected any non-javascript things, so those probably just need to be rerun?
Cake if we can come up with a nicer way to tell the user what's going on than a modal dialog.
send a message to the notification widget?
I hadn't thought of that! I'll try playing around with the notification widget and see how that looks.
